pullRequest.body:
This file defines finite places of a number field `K` as absolute values coming from an embedding
into a completion of `K` associated to a non-zero prime ideal of `ùìû K` with some basic APIs.

This is part of a project which aims to define heights. The next step is the product formula.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [fb8a89cd12](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19667/commits/fb8a89cd12db32893382ef667418ba7f5d6ddbe1)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.NumberField.FinitePlaces` (new file)|2401|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ FinitePlace`
`+ FinitePlace.mk`
`+ FinitePlace.norm_def`
`+ apply`
`+ embedding`
`+ eq_iff_eq`
`+ instNormedFieldValuedAdicCompletion`
`+ instRankOneValuedAdicCompletion`
`+ instance : FunLike (FinitePlace K) K ‚Ñù`
`+ instance : MonoidWithZeroHomClass (FinitePlace K) K ‚Ñù`
`+ instance : NonnegHomClass (FinitePlace K) K ‚Ñù`
`+ le_iff_le`
`+ max_ideal_mk`
`+ maximal_ideal`
`+ mk_eq_iff`
`+ mk_max_ideal`
`+ mulSupport_Finite`
`+ mulSupport_Finite_int`
`+ norm_embedding_eq`
`+ norm_eq_one_iff_not_mem`
`+ norm_le_one`
`+ norm_lt_one_iff_mem`
`+ one_lt_norm`
`+ pos_iff`
`+ vadic_abv`
`+ vadic_abv_def`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

```suggestion
    exact (v.asIdeal.fintypeQuotientOfFreeOfNeBot v.ne_bot).finite
```
Dot notation allows to write this more compactly.

```suggestion
  toFun x := toNNReal (norm_ne_zero v) (v.valuation x)
  map_mul' _ _ := by simp only [_root_.map_mul, NNReal.coe_mul]
  nonneg' _ := NNReal.zero_le_coe
  eq_zero' _ := by simp only [NNReal.coe_eq_zero, map_eq_zero]
  add_le' x y := by
```
This is notation that tends to be more readable.

```suggestion
    -- the triangle inequality is implied by the ultrametric one
```

```suggestion
    have h_mono := (toNNReal_strictMono (one_lt_norm v)).monotone
    rw [‚Üê h_mono.map_max] --max goes inside withZeroMultIntToNNReal
    exact h_mono (v.valuation.map_add x y)
```
if you want to use dot notation. (It is a matter of taste and takes some getting used to.)

```suggestion
noncomputable def vadicAbv : AbsoluteValue K ‚Ñù where
```
This is a term of a non-Prop type, so should be in lower camel case as per the [naming convention](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html) (point 4).

```suggestion
/-- The embedding of a `NumberField` inside its completion with respect to `v`. -/
```
if you want to use the lean name, or
```suggestion
/-- The embedding of a number field inside its completion with respect to `v`. -/
```

```suggestion
  @UniformSpace.Completion.coeRingHom K _ v.adicValued.toUniformSpace _ _
```
what comes after the `:=` is indented two spaces.

```suggestion
  Valued.toNormedField (adicCompletion K v) (WithZero (Multiplicative ‚Ñ§))
```

```suggestion
def FinitePlace (K : Type*) [Field K] [NumberField K] :=
  {w : AbsoluteValue K ‚Ñù //
```
If the definition doesn't fit on the remainder of the line, it should start in the following line (with 2 spaces indentation).

```suggestion
  ‚ü®place (embedding v), ‚ü®v, rfl‚ü©‚ü©
```

The `rfl` here points to a missing API lemma (note that `NNReal.coe_inj` above is not actually used by `simp`) of the form `(WithZeroMulInt.toNNReal _ (Valued.v x) : ‚Ñù) = (vadic_abv v) x` or similar (whose proof will be `rfl`).

```suggestion
    (norm_ne_zero v) (one_lt_norm v).ne', valuation_eq_intValuationDef,
```
Dot notation simplifies this.

```suggestion
  exact (intValuation_le_one v x).ge_iff_eq.symm
```
Same here.
The opening gambits of this and the next two proofs are quite similar. It may be a good idea to state a lemma for this and then use it in these proofs.

```suggestion
  coe_injective' _ _ h := Subtype.eq (AbsoluteValue.ext fun x ‚Ü¶ congr_fun h x)
```
This is the preferred style in Mathlib.
But this is shorter:
```suggestion
  coe_injective' _ _ h := Subtype.eq (AbsoluteValue.ext <| congr_fun h)
```

```suggestion
  map_mul w := w.1.map_mul
```
like below.

```suggestion
  apply_nonneg w := w.1.nonneg
```

```suggestion
  rw [show w x = (mk (maximal_ideal w)) x by simp only [mk_max_ideal], apply]
```
(Here `apply` is the API lemma that deals with the `rfl`.)

```suggestion
    ‚àÄ v : HeightOneSpectrum (ùìû K), ‚Äñembedding v x‚Äñ = r :=
  Set.forall_subtype_range_iff
```
(See above.)

```suggestion
    ‚àÄ v : HeightOneSpectrum (ùìû K), ‚Äñembedding v x‚Äñ ‚â§ r :=
  Set.forall_subtype_range_iff
```

This statement looks strange: under which circumstances would one consider elements whose valuations at all finite places are the same? (Unless perhaps `r = 1`  or `r = 0`, but then a specialized version would likely be more useful.)

```suggestion
  have ‚ü®x, hx1, hx2‚ü© : ‚àÉ x : ùìû K, x ‚àà v‚ÇÅ.asIdeal ‚àß x ‚àâ v‚ÇÇ.asIdeal := by
    by_contra! H
    exact h <| HeightOneSpectrum.ext_iff.mpr (IsMaximal.eq_of_le (isMaximal v‚ÇÅ) IsPrime.ne_top' H)
```
Some shortcuts.

```suggestion
noncomputable def maximalIdeal (w : FinitePlace K) : HeightOneSpectrum (ùìû K) := w.2.choose
```
See above. Names referring to it should then also contain `maximalIdeal` (instead of `max_ideal`).

```suggestion
theorem mulSupport_finite_int {x : ùìû K} (h_x_nezero : x ‚â† 0) :
```
(Point 5 of the naming conventions.)

```suggestion
    (Function.mulSupport fun w : FinitePlace K ‚Ü¶ w x).Finite := by
```

```suggestion
    exact ne_iff_lt_iff_le.mpr this
```
We don't need `Decidable` here.
Maybe add the injectivity of `maximalIdeal` as a separate lemma?

```suggestion
  have h_inj : Set.InjOn FinitePlace.maximal_ideal {w | w.maximal_ideal.asIdeal ‚à£ span {x}} := by
```
The function already has a name (and `x_1` does not look nice).

```suggestion
  have h_subs : FinitePlace.maximal_ideal ''
      {w : FinitePlace K | w.maximal_ideal.asIdeal ‚à£ span {x}} ‚äÜ
```
(unnecessary parens, plus see above.)

The final bit of the proof (from the `apply Set.Finite.of_fiinite_image` line on) can be written using "backwards reasoning" as follows:
```
  refine Set.Finite.of_finite_image (Set.Finite.subset h ?_) h_inj
  simp only [dvd_span_singleton, Set.image_subset_iff, Set.preimage_setOf_eq, subset_refl]
```

```suggestion
    (Function.mulSupport fun w : FinitePlace K ‚Ü¶ w x).Finite := by
```

```suggestion
  rcases IsFractionRing.div_surjective (A := ùìû K) x with ‚ü®a, b, hb, rfl‚ü©
```
Named implicit arguments help avoid `@`, and there is the `rfl` trick.

```suggestion
  simp_rw [‚Üê RingOfIntegers.coe_eq_algebraMap]
```
`simp_rw` rewrites repeatedly.

```suggestion
  apply ((mulSupport_Finite_int ha).union (mulSupport_Finite_int hb)).subset
```
Dot notation again (a matter of taste).

This can be simplified a bit:
```suggestion
  simp only [Function.mem_mulSupport, ne_eq, Set.mem_union]
  contrapose!
  simp +contextual only [ne_eq, one_ne_zero, not_false_eq_true, div_self, implies_true]
```
The `apply` and `intro` lines can be combined (again, a matter of taste):
```lean
  refine ((mulSupport_Finite_int ha).union (mulSupport_Finite_int hb)).subset fun w ‚Ü¶ ?_
```

```suggestion
theorem mulSupport_finite {x : K} (h_x_nezero : x ‚â† 0) :
```

pullRequest.title: feat(NumberTheory/NumberField/FinitePlaces): the finite places of a number field
